*Enhancement Description*
Provide a way for the user to access their favorites and bookmarks from any page without having to navigate to another page.

*Use Case*
On my company's wiki, I use two main methods to navigate to pages I deal with on a daily basis:
# My list of favorites, viewable on the Dashboard
# Drilling down from the main page of the space I am interested in until I get to the page I am looking for (and if I deal with it daily I am going to be adding it as a favorite so I can skip this process in the future)

Based on the fact that my favorites are essentially a list of bookmarks that I want to visit no matter where I am on the Internet or browsing the rest of the wiki, having to go back to the Dashboard is an extra step that is unnecessary/undesired.
fields.summary: Favorites/Bookmarks Visible on Every Page

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11758].
  {panel}

Originally created as request for metadata plugin enhancement and the developer suggested I request this from confluence instead.

We use confluence and metadata for more detailed planning and collaboration of issues that we track in Jira. It would be very nice to have metadata fields in the wiki captured from jira fields from the related issue in Jira. For example, I have an issue in Jira with a priority number attached to it. In the wiki I would want to define a piece of metadata such as: {metadata-jira:Priority}PM-32{metadata-jira}

and this would resolve the metadata to the priority field for the issue PM-32 in my configured Jira instance. I would then be able to reference this piece of metadata in metadata reports and charts.

Hi Ken,

I don't want to add JIRA support to the Metadata Plugin, because that opens the floodgates to similar integration requests with other applications out there. Instead I suggest that you request that Confluence create a new JIRA macro that can give you back data about any project. You can then use this macro as metadata as you describe.

e.g something like:
{metadata-value:Priority}{jira-value:priority|issue=PM-32}{metadata-value}

Note that this requires that the jira-value macro knows how to access your JIRA instance. For example, the jira-issues macro requires that you pass that information every time. Anyway, that is something for the Confluence and JIRA teams to agree upon.

If you agree with this approach, then I will close this issue.

Thanks,

    * Andy

It would be really nice to have a possibility to list *recently updated personal spaces*. It is possible to create rss feed listing changed content from personal spaces only, but that isn't usable if one or two users are much more active than others or if there has been many changes recently. Thus, it would be nice to see a list of changed *spaces* making it is easy to see if someone has created new content in one's personal space.

This feature could be included in Recently Updated Macro, and maybe this functionality could be included in browsepeople.action-page, too (some kind of sorting order perhaps). Macro could list the most recent change(s) in a space (configurable amount) and a picture of that space. 

Here is an example of macro showing two recent changes per space:
|| :) Anne's space | List of hobbies | by Anne (04 May) |
|| :) Bob's space | Re: Bob's blog | by Charlie (03 May)  | 
| | Bob's blog | by Bob (03 May)  | 
|| :) Charlie's space | How I... | by Charlie (02 May) |  

This feature is important because it would encourage users to update their personal spaces ([this is important specially for new users|http://www.wikipatterns.com/display/wikipatterns/MySpace]) and make it easier to find other users' personal spaces.

If there already is some way to do this I apologize the fuzz ;)

I have 2 suggestions related to users and group management in the Administration section of Confluence.

1) Have the number of users displayed when viewing the group members (Administration-->Manage Groups-->Group Members) configurable.  This would essentially be the same functionality that is on the Manage Users screen available through the Show (10, 20, 50, 100) option.  The old version of Confluence we used would display all group members, while 2.8 displays 10 members per page.  Some people like more, some less, so it would be a nice-to-have to be able to select this dynamically.

2) When creating a new group, it would be great to be able to add members in bulk.  Currently I have to create the group, then search for each individual user, edit their groups, and add them to the new group.  It would be more efficient if when the group is created (or alternatively have an option from the Manage Groups-->Group Members screen) to multi-select users to add to the group as a single add operation.

Thanks for considering these enhancements,
Barry Pape

A few versions ago of Confluence, drafts were moved from being simple objects stored in their own table, to be ContentEntityObjects stored in the Content table.  Rows in the Content table that represent drafts, contain values for draftpageid, draftspacekey, draftpageversion and drafttype.  

They contain NULL for pageid and spaceid.  There seems to be no reason at all that they couldn't use pageid and spaceid instead of their own values. 

I suspect draftpageversion could quite adequately use version, which is always 1 for drafts, but I can see that the columns have slightly different meanings and therefore have a reason for being separate.

drafttype is always the type of the page to which draftpageid refers.  I haven't researched whether there is a good argument for repeating it here or whether it would be just as useful to retrieve it by the reasonably simple join of draftpageid (or if I have my way just pageid) = contentid.
fields.summary: Drafts should be refactored to use existing parts of ContentEntityObject

"If someone grants anonymous access to a space, then all "registered/non-anonymous/logged-in" users can view that space too. It doesn't make sense if a logged in user to have less permissions than an anonymous user. That means, Confluence only cares that the anonymous "view" permissions have been given to that space and that the logged in user has 'can use' permission."

The WARNING message in the space should be enhanced to further explains the above scenario. Ideally, it should says:

WARNING:  Anonymous users will not be able to view this space, because they have not been granted the global 'Use Confluence' permission. 
You can grant anonymous access to Confluence from global permissions.
*NOTE: logged-in users, if not explicitly granted permission to this space, will receive the 'anonymous' rights below"*

CONF-7409 was implemented for Confluence 2.8, allowing macros to use #requireResource (or WebResourceManager.requireResource()) to declare which CSS and JS resources they required when the page was built.

This functionality doesn't currently extend to including these resources in the following situations:

-preview in the editor: need to get the resources via AJAX from the server and include them in the page dynamically- (see CONF-11982)
- exports and notifications: use a hard-coded list of resources generated by /styles/combined.css?forWysiwyg=true

(The rich-text editor is less important because only Confluence macros typically render content that needs to be styled there. Most just appear as \{macro}...\{macro}.)

When a merge conflict occurs, the user is given a screen that contains:
* An error message
* A change report
* *Overwrite* and *Cancel* buttons
* An editor.

The error message says: 
{panel:bgColor=#fbb}
You were editing an outdated version of this page. Another user has updated this page before you. Your changes against the now updated version is shown below. Please decide whether your changes should overwrite it or you wish to discard your changes.
{panel}

What the user is actually expected to do if they're playing fair is:
* Look through the change report
* Merge any changes from the change report into their own submission in the editor
* Click Overwrite

Interestingly, the UI differs from [the documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Concurrent+Editing+and+Merging+Changes] so it has clearly changed at some stage in the past.  
It seems that some users don't realise they can update their entry with changes from the merge report before clicking Overwrite.  That doesn't seem too surprising to me given that the error message doesn't give "updating their changes" as an option let alone a suggestion.
fields.summary: The UI for merging changes after a page editing conflict is unclear

Steps to reproduce. 

1) Install a standalone copy of confluence. Set the context to be "/confluence" so you access the local instance as "http://localhost:8080/confluence". 

Now suppose the customer has setup a Web server such as Apache that accesses this server using the URL "http://my.confluence.com", thus has no context. (You don't need to setup Apache to reproduce this, simply keep following the below steps.

2) Change you Server base URL to be "http://my.confluence.com"

3) Export a space (which has attachments, one of which is an image attachment and is displayed on the page) in html format. You will find that the image attachment is located within the export in both export/confluence/download/attachment/.../.../image.jpg and export/download/attachment/.../../image.jpg. 

To reproduce this behaviour more easily I have included a space export. 
After completing step 1,2 above, do the following. 
a) Import the export into your 2.7.3 install. 
b) export the space as a html file. 


Customers should be able to have two different contexts and still not have a duplicate files in the export.
fields.summary: Setting Server Base Url to have a different context causes HTML exports to store two files for the one image attachment.

I went to a roadshow for Salesforce.com yesterday and one of the features of their product was a document management solution they have called "Content".

One feature they had which I would find useful was the ability to subscribe to individual attachments si that you were notified whenever a change was made.

Now I know that you can create a custom feed for a page to be notified whenever an attachment is changed but if a page had 10 attachments I may only want to know about changes to 2 of them.

For example, there is a page on EAC which the PST uses to attach all files relating to our webinars. Say Boots looks after the slides for the Confluence webinar. I download the file on Monday and subscribe to the attachment. Boots updates the file on Tuesday. I get a notification that the file has been updated so I can then download the latest version.

Not sure how much work is involved in this but I think it would be a great feature to have to boost our sales pitch of using Confluence to replace your shared network drive or document management system.
fields.summary: Add ability for users to subscribe or watch to individual attachment updates

*Current functionality*

Currently when you navigate by labels you can add or remove additional labels to your selection. When you select a label the results that are returned provide "Related Labels". Selecting the first additional related label filters the results further. Beyond a combination selection "X+Y" related labels is not as effective as it could be.

For example access the [label for macro|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro] in Confluence Documentation space
Now select the label ["plugin"|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin].
Results are further refined; macro+plugin.

Now select "column" resulting in [macro+plugin+column|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin+column]
No results are returned.

*Consider enhancing the UI/navigational element of the labels by providing better "filtering" of labels.*

For example, after making the [macro+plugin|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin] selection, the resulting "related labels" would only contain labels that are being utilized on the results for macro+plugin.

The resulting effect is that the user would be able to "drill down" and further refine their set of results from the label results page. This kind of filtering mechanism would be very powerful for navigating and locating information.

Thanks for the consideration.
fields.summary: Navigating Pages by Labels - Label set filters on usage

  {panel}

The linking-feature should support a create-somewhere feature.

e.g. i've got a page "application" in which i've a link referring to a specific server. If this serverpage doesn't exist a page is created as a child of the application, instead of beeing a child of "Server".

it could look like [websrv:parent=Server]

I know that the {link-page} macro already provides this, but this macro is not supported by the {incoming-links} macro, so i think it's easier to extend the standard link-plugin.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11364].
  {panel}

I'd like to be to have multiple {recently-updated} in order to separate recently updated news/blog from pages from discussion/comments. When I try this, the section titles are the same (so an ability to set title would be helpful) and when "view more" function only impacts the first {recently-updated} section even when the "+" is clicked for a different {recently-updated} section. In the example, I'm trying to accomplish this on the dashboard layout.

$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=news|showProfilePic=false}") - 10 displayed
$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=page,attachment|showProfilePic=false}")  - 10 displayed
$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=comment|showProfilePic=false}")  - 10 displayed, click "+" here

Result:
$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=news|showProfilePic=false}") - 20 displayed
$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=page,attachment|showProfilePic=false}")  - 10 displayed
$helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{recently-updated:dashboard|types=comment|showProfilePic=false}")  - 10 displayed
fields.summary: Multiple instances of {recently-updated} on one page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11314].
  {panel}



When we create a page with certain characters, like an apostrophe, in the title, those characters show up in the URL for that page. Some of the security tools (e.g SiteMinder)  block URLs with these characters, which then make the page unreachable. For example a title of "Terry's Tasks" results in a URL like http://localhost:8080/confluence/display/spacename/Terry%27s+Tasks

Confluence should : 
 
1) Strip characters from the title when generating the URL (e.g. http://localhost:8080/confluence/display/spacename/Terrys+Tasks )

OR 

2) Prevent the creation of pages with these characters in the title.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11285].
  {panel}

Hi,

When including different characters in page names - like %, &, +, etc., the URL is generated differently.

A usual URL (including the page name) looks like this: http://www.gigaspaces.com/wiki/display/GS6/Welcome+to+GigaSpaces

BUT if you add a character in the page name (for example, naming a page, C++), the URL would look like this: http://www.gigaspaces.com/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=36864161

which is less nice-looking to say the least, and also then all URLs in the wiki aren't standard.

Is it possible to change this?

If it's been fixed in a future version, I'll be glad to know.

Thanks,

Limor
fields.summary: Page names with special characters to generate regular URL
